clean_content:
Definition / general

* Ectopic sebaceous glands within oral cavity or on vermillion border of lips

Essential features

* Appear as yellow-white, asymptomatic 1 - 3 mm papules in the oral cavity or lip vermillion* May be hyperplastic and nodular* Neoplastic transformation very rare but reported ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol 1991;72:709](1812454), [Head Neck 2016;38:E20](25899035), [Case Rep Dent 2018;2018:3054931](30116646))* Have been associated with Lynch and Muir-Torre syndromes ([Gut 2005;54:1279](15879014), [J Oral Pathol Med 2015;44:552](25213213))* Present in ~80 - 90% of the population ([Med Clin North Am 2014;98:1281](25443677))

ICD coding

* ICD-10: [Q38.6](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/Q00-Q99/Q38-Q45/Q38-/Q38.6) - other congenital malformations of the mouth

Epidemiology

* No sex or racial predilection* Often most prominent after puberty ([Med Clin North Am 2014;98:1281](25443677))* Hyperplastic examples have been associated with Lynch and Muir-Torre syndromes ([Gut 2005;54:1279](15879014), [J Oral Pathol Med 2015;44:552](25213213))* Patients with high densities of Fordyce granules may have higher lipid profiles ([Dent Res J (Isfahan) 2014;11:553](25426145))

Sites

* Buccal mucosa (often bilateral), upper lip vermilion border, mandibular retromolar pad and tonsillar areas* Similar anomalies affect the areolae, glans penis and labia minora

Etiology

* Congenital* Considered benign sebaceous hamartomas

Clinical features

* Yellow-white, asymptomatic, floral appearing 1 - 3 mm papules that remain constant throughout life* May be hyperplastic and nodular

Diagnosis

* Diagnosed clinically* Rarely may require biopsy for identification when hyperplastic or nodular

Treatment

* No treatment necessary unless for cosmetic reasons

Clinical images

Contributed by Molly Housley Smith, D.M.D.  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityfordyceclinicalSmith01.jpeg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityfordyceclinicalSmith01.jpeg)

Yellow, floral papules

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityfordyceclinicalSmith02.jpeg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityfordyceclinicalSmith02.jpeg)

1 - 3 mm yellow-white papules

  
  
Image hosted on other servers:  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/oralcavityfordycencbi01.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3283840/figure/F1/)

Yellow-white papules

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Similar to normal sebaceous glands of skin but lack hair follicles and almost always lack ductal communication with surface* Parakeratotic stratified squamous epithelium overlies the sebaceous lobules

Microscopic (histologic) images

*Contributed by Molly Housley Smith, D.M.D.*  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityfordycemicroSmith01.jpeg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityfordycemicroSmith01.jpeg)

Oral mucosa containing sebaceous lobules

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityfordycemicroSmith02.jpeg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityfordycemicroSmith02.jpeg)

Sebaceous lobules adjacent to mucous glands

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityfordycemicroSmith03.jpeg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityfordycemicroSmith03.jpeg)

Sebaceous lobules

Positive stains

* Although associated with Lynch and Muir-Torre syndromes, which demonstrate defects in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) proteins leading to microsatellite instability, preservation of MMR proteins is noted upon immunostaining of Fordyce granules ([Appl Immunohistochem Mol Morphol 2017;25:209](26894645))

Sample pathology report

* Left buccal mucosa, incision:
  + Fordyce granules (see comment)+ Comment: Microscopic examination reveals parakeratotic stratified squamous epithelium
      overlying mesenchymal tissue. Within the mesenchymal stroma are numerous sebaceous gland
      lobules. Hair follicles are not appreciated.

Differential diagnosis

* Clinically diagnostic and doesn't have a differential diagnosis; often are not even biopsied but found only incidentally on pathology* Usually noted on routine examination
